title: Understanding Leniency Designs: Why Your Examiner Matters (And How to Estimate It Right)
section: The Setup: Why We Need Instruments
text:
The Setup: Why We Need Instruments
Let‚Äôs start with the patent example. We want to know: Does getting a patent cause startups to be more innovative?
The outcome equation is straightforward:
\[y_i = \gamma + \beta x_i + \varepsilon_i\]
where: - \(y_i\) is future innovation (e.g., number of future patent applications) - \(x_i\) is whether patent \(i\) was approved (0 or 1) - \(\beta\) is the causal effect we want to estimate - \(\varepsilon_i\) captures unobserved factors

The Selection Problem
The challenge is selection bias. Startups with strong applications (high \(\varepsilon_i\)) are both:

More likely to get their patents approved
More likely to be innovative in the future anyway

This creates a positive correlation between \(x_i\) and \(\varepsilon_i\), meaning OLS will overestimate the true causal effect.
Let‚Äôs simulate this to see it in action:


Show code
library(tidyverse)
library(knitr)
library(kableExtra)
library(plotly)

set.seed(42)

# Simulation parameters
n <- 500
true_effect <- 0.25

# Generate data with selection
simulate_selection_data <- function() {
  data <- tibble(
    startup_id = 1:n,
    # Unobserved quality (part of epsilon)
    quality = rnorm(n, mean = 0, sd = 1),
    # Approval depends on quality (selection!)
    approval_prob = pnorm(quality * 0.8),
    approved = rbinom(n, 1, approval_prob),
    # Outcome depends on quality AND treatment
    innovation = 5 + true_effect * approved + quality + rnorm(n, 0, 0.5)
  )
  return(data)
}

data_selected <- simulate_selection_data()

# Compare OLS to truth
ols_estimate <- coef(lm(innovation ~ approved, data = data_selected))["approved"]

# Visualize the selection problem
p1 <- ggplot(data_selected, aes(x = quality, y = innovation, color = factor(approved))) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.6, size = 2) +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = TRUE, size = 1.2) +
  scale_color_manual(
    values = c("0" = "#e74c3c", "1" = "#27ae60"),
    labels = c("Denied", "Approved")
  ) +
  labs(
    title = "The Selection Problem",
    subtitle = sprintf("OLS estimates effect = %.3f, but true effect = %.3f", 
                      ols_estimate, true_effect),
    x = "Startup Quality (Unobserved)",
    y = "Future Innovation",
    color = "Patent Status"
  ) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 13) +
  theme(
    legend.position = "bottom",
    plot.title = element_text(face = "bold", size = 16),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(color = "#666666")
  )

print(p1)









The plot shows the problem clearly: approved startups (green) have higher innovation partly because they were approved, but also because they had higher quality to begin with. OLS attributes all of the difference to the treatment, leading to overestimation.

title: Understanding Leniency Designs: Why Your Examiner Matters (And How to Estimate It Right)
section: The Solution: Using Examiner Assignment as an Instrument
text:
The Solution: Using Examiner Assignment as an Instrument

The Simple Two-Examiner Case
Let‚Äôs start simple. Suppose we have just two examiners:

Examiner T (Tough): Approves 40% of applications

Examiner S (Soft): Approves 70% of applications

If assignment is random, we can use examiner assignment as an instrument!


Show code
# Simulate data with two examiners
simulate_two_examiner_data <- function(n = 500, 
                                       tough_rate = 0.4, 
                                       soft_rate = 0.7,
                                       true_effect = 0.25) {
  data <- tibble(
    startup_id = 1:n,
    quality = rnorm(n, 0, 1),
    # Random assignment to examiner
    examiner = sample(c("Tough", "Soft"), n, replace = TRUE),
    # Approval probability depends on examiner AND quality
    approval_prob = ifelse(
      examiner == "Soft",
      pmin(soft_rate + 0.1 * quality, 0.95),
      pmin(tough_rate + 0.1 * quality, 0.95)
    ),
    approved = rbinom(n, 1, approval_prob),
    # Outcome
    innovation = 5 + true_effect * approved + quality + rnorm(n, 0, 0.5)
  )
  return(data)
}

data_two_exam <- simulate_two_examiner_data()

# Create instrument: indicator for soft examiner
data_two_exam <- data_two_exam %>%
  mutate(soft_examiner = ifelse(examiner == "Soft", 1, 0))

# Run IV regression manually (Wald estimator)
mean_y_soft <- mean(data_two_exam$innovation[data_two_exam$soft_examiner == 1])
mean_y_tough <- mean(data_two_exam$innovation[data_two_exam$soft_examiner == 0])
mean_x_soft <- mean(data_two_exam$approved[data_two_exam$soft_examiner == 1])
mean_x_tough <- mean(data_two_exam$approved[data_two_exam$soft_examiner == 0])

iv_estimate <- (mean_y_soft - mean_y_tough) / (mean_x_soft - mean_x_tough)

# Visualize
exam_summary <- data_two_exam %>%
  group_by(examiner) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_innovation = mean(innovation),
    approval_rate = mean(approved),
    n = n()
  )

p2 <- ggplot(exam_summary, aes(x = examiner, y = mean_innovation, fill = examiner)) +
  geom_col(width = 0.6) +
  geom_errorbar(
    aes(ymin = mean_innovation - 0.1, ymax = mean_innovation + 0.1),
    width = 0.2
  ) +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("Soft" = "#27ae60", "Tough" = "#e67e22")) +
  labs(
    title = "Average Innovation by Assigned Examiner",
    subtitle = sprintf("IV estimate: %.3f (True effect: %.3f)", iv_estimate, true_effect),
    x = "Assigned Examiner",
    y = "Mean Future Innovation"
  ) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 13) +
  theme(
    legend.position = "none",
    plot.title = element_text(face = "bold", size = 16)
  ) +
  geom_text(
    aes(label = sprintf("Approval rate: %.1f%%", approval_rate * 100)),
    vjust = -1.5,
    size = 4
  )

print(p2)









Why this works:

Examiner assignment is random, so it‚Äôs uncorrelated with startup quality (\(\varepsilon_i\))
Examiner leniency affects approval probability (relevance)
Examiner assignment only affects innovation through the approval decision (exclusion)

The IV estimate recovers something close to the true effect!

title: Understanding Leniency Designs: Why Your Examiner Matters (And How to Estimate It Right)
text:
The Many-Examiner Problem
In reality, patent offices don‚Äôt have two examiners‚Äîthey have hundreds or thousands. With \(K\) examiners, we need \(K-1\) instruments (one indicator for each examiner, dropping one reference category).
This creates a problem called many-weak instrument bias.

Why 2SLS Breaks Down
Here‚Äôs the subtle issue with two-stage least squares (2SLS):

First stage: Regress approval on all examiner dummies to get predicted approval \(\hat{x}_i\)
Second stage: Regress outcome on predicted approval

The problem? To predict approval for application \(i\), 2SLS calculates examiner \(j\)‚Äôs approval rate using all applications assigned to \(j\)‚Äîincluding application \(i\) itself!
This creates a mechanical correlation between the instrument and the error term. The very thing we‚Äôre trying to avoid.
Let me show you how bad it gets:

    Figure 3: Many-Examiner Bias Increases with K
    
        
            Number of examiners (K):
            
            50
        
        
            Sample size (n):
            
            1000
        
        Run Simulation (500 iterations)
    
    
        
        
    




The problem is clear: As the number of examiners (K) increases relative to sample size, 2SLS becomes increasingly biased toward OLS. Even when examiners collectively explain meaningful variation, the mechanical correlation pulls 2SLS estimates toward the biased OLS estimates.



The Bias Formula
Under homoskedasticity, the 2SLS bias can be approximated as:
\[\text{Bias}(2SLS) \approx \text{Bias}(OLS) \times \frac{1}{E[F]}\]
where \(E[F]\) is the expected first-stage F-statistic. The famous ‚ÄúF > 10‚Äù rule of thumb comes from wanting 2SLS bias to be less than 10% of OLS bias.
But with many examiners, even when they collectively explain meaningful variation, \(F\) can be small because it‚Äôs divided by \(K\).

title: Understanding Leniency Designs: Why Your Examiner Matters (And How to Estimate It Right)
text:
The UJIVE Solution
The Unbiased Jackknife Instrumental Variables Estimator (UJIVE) solves this with an elegant idea:
When estimating examiner \(j\)‚Äôs leniency for application \(i\), leave application \(i\) out.

The Leave-One-Out Principle
Let me show you exactly what this means:

    Figure 4: The Leave-One-Out Principle
    
        
    




The key difference: For application 4 (highlighted), 2SLS includes application 4‚Äôs own approval when calculating Examiner C‚Äôs leniency (5/7 = 71%), while UJIVE excludes it (4/6 = 67%). This breaks the mechanical correlation between the instrument and the error term.



How Well Does UJIVE Work?
Let‚Äôs compare all three estimators side-by-side with a large simulation:

    Figure 5: UJIVE vs 2SLS - Full Comparison
    
        
        
            Run 1,000 Simulations
        
        
    



The results speak for themselves: UJIVE is centered on the true effect, while 2SLS is pulled toward the biased OLS estimate.

title: Understanding Leniency Designs: Why Your Examiner Matters (And How to Estimate It Right)
text:
Visualizing the Leave-One-Out Idea
Let me create a visual that shows exactly what UJIVE is doing differently:


Show code
# Create a small example with one examiner
set.seed(123)
small_example <- tibble(
  application = 1:7,
  examiner = "Examiner A",
  approved = c(1, 0, 1, 1, 0, 1, 1),
  highlight = c(rep(FALSE, 3), TRUE, rep(FALSE, 3))
)

# Calculate approval rates
overall_rate <- mean(small_example$approved)
loo_rate <- mean(small_example$approved[!small_example$highlight])

# Create visualization data
viz_data <- tibble(
  Method = c("2SLS", "UJIVE"),
  `Approval Rate` = c(overall_rate, loo_rate),
  Description = c(
    sprintf("Uses all 7 observations\nRate = %.3f (5/7)", overall_rate),
    sprintf("Leaves out observation 4\nRate = %.3f (4/6)", loo_rate)

)

# Plot the grid of applications
p6a <- ggplot(small_example, aes(x = application, y = 1, fill = factor(approved))) +
  geom_tile(aes(color = ifelse(highlight, "highlighted", "normal")),
            size = 3, width = 0.8, height = 0.8) +
  geom_text(aes(label = ifelse(approved == 1, "‚úì", "‚úó")),
            size = 8, color = "white", fontface = "bold") +
  scale_fill_manual(
    values = c("0" = "#e74c3c", "1" = "#27ae60"),
    labels = c("Denied", "Approved"),
    name = "Decision"

  ) +

  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(face = "bold", size = 14, hjust = 0.5),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 11, hjust = 0.5, margin = margin(b = 10)),
    legend.position = "bottom"
  )

# Plot the rates
p6b <- ggplot(viz_data, aes(x = Method, y = `Approval Rate`, fill = Method)) +
  geom_col(width = 0.6) +
  geom_text(aes(label = Description), vjust = -0.5, size = 3.5, lineheight = 0.9) +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("2SLS" = "#3498db", "UJIVE" = "#9b59b6")) +
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 0.9), labels = scales::percent_format()) +
  labs(
    title = "Leniency Calculation for Application 4",
    y = "Estimated Examiner Approval Rate"
  ) +

)









The key insight: For application 4 (highlighted in black), 2SLS includes application 4‚Äôs own approval when calculating Examiner A‚Äôs leniency, while UJIVE excludes it. This breaks the mechanical correlation between the instrument and the error term.

title: Understanding Leniency Designs: Why Your Examiner Matters (And How to Estimate It Right)
text:
Heterogeneous Treatment Effects
So far we‚Äôve assumed patent approval has the same effect on all startups. But in reality, effects probably vary‚Äîsome startups might benefit more from patent protection than others.
Good news: UJIVE has a clear interpretation even with heterogeneous effects, thanks to the Local Average Treatment Effect (LATE) framework.

The Complier Story
With many examiners, we can think of ‚Äúcompliers‚Äù for each examiner pair:

Compliers for pair (Tough, Soft): Applications that Soft would approve but Tough would deny
Different examiner pairs have different complier groups

UJIVE identifies a weighted average of treatment effects across all complier groups, where the weights are proportional to:

The size of the complier group (more compliers = more weight)
The squared leniency difference (larger differences = more weight)

Importantly, the weights are positive under the monotonicity assumption‚Äîno examiner pair receives negative weight.
Let me simulate heterogeneous effects and show that UJIVE still works:


Show code
# Simulate with heterogeneous effects
simulate_het_effects <- function(n_startups = 1000, n_examiners = 50) {
  examiners <- tibble(
    examiner_id = 1:n_examiners,
    leniency = rnorm(n_examiners, 0.5, 0.15)
  ) %>%
    mutate(leniency = pmax(0.2, pmin(0.8, leniency)))
  
  data <- tibble(
    startup_id = 1:n_startups,
    quality = rnorm(n_startups, 0, 1),
    # Heterogeneous treatment effects
    # Effect is larger for low-quality startups (they benefit more from patent)
    individual_effect = 0.5 - 0.15 * quality,
    examiner_id = sample(1:n_examiners, n_startups, replace = TRUE)
  ) %>%
    left_join(examiners, by = "examiner_id") %>%
    mutate(
      approval_prob = pmin(leniency + 0.08 * quality, 0.95),
      approved = rbinom(n_startups, 1, approval_prob),
      innovation = 5 + individual_effect * approved + quality + rnorm(n_startups, 0, 0.5)
    )
  
  # True ATE
  ate <- mean(data$individual_effect)
  
  return(list(data = data, ate = ate))
}

# Run simulation
result <- simulate_het_effects()
data_het <- result$data
true_ate <- result$ate

# Estimate with UJIVE
data_het$examiner_factor <- factor(data_het$examiner_id)
ujive_het <- ujive_estimate(data_het)

# For comparison, simple IV with 2 examiners would recover LATE for those compliers
# Let's see the distribution of individual effects
p7 <- ggplot(data_het, aes(x = individual_effect, fill = factor(approved))) +
  geom_density(alpha = 0.6) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = true_ate, linetype = "dashed", size = 1, color = "black") +
  geom_vline(xintercept = ujive_het, linetype = "solid", size = 1, color = "#9b59b6") +
  scale_fill_manual(
    values = c("0" = "#e74c3c", "1" = "#27ae60"),
    labels = c("Denied", "Approved"),
    name = "Patent Status"
  ) +
  annotate("text", x = true_ate, y = Inf, label = "True ATE", 
           vjust = 1.5, hjust = -0.1, size = 3.5) +
  annotate("text", x = ujive_het, y = Inf, label = "UJIVE",
           vjust = 3, hjust = -0.1, size = 3.5, color = "#9b59b6") +
  labs(
    title = "Heterogeneous Treatment Effects",
    subtitle = sprintf("True ATE = %.3f, UJIVE estimate = %.3f", true_ate, ujive_het),
    x = "Individual Treatment Effect",
    y = "Density"
  ) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 13) +
  theme(
    legend.position = "bottom",
    plot.title = element_text(face = "bold", size = 16)
  )

print(p7)









UJIVE estimates a weighted average of treatment effects, where compliers (startups near the approval margin) receive more weight. This is exactly what we want‚Äîthese are the startups whose outcomes are actually affected by examiner assignment.

title: Understanding Leniency Designs: Why Your Examiner Matters (And How to Estimate It Right)
text:
Real-World Application: Startup Patents
Now let‚Äôs look at real results from Farre-Mensa, Hegde, and Ljungqvist (2020), who study whether patent approval helps startups become more innovative.
They analyze 32,514 first-time patent applications with data on:

Treatment: Whether the patent was approved
Outcomes: Future patent applications, approvals, citations
Setting: US Patent Office with ~1,200 examiners
Assignment: Within art unit (technology area) and year

The paper originally used a constructed leniency measure. Let‚Äôs compare their results to UJIVE:

title: Leniency Designs: Why You‚Äôve Been Doing Them Wrong (And How to Fix It)
text:
A Practical Checklist
The paper provides a 5-step guide for implementing leniency designs. Here‚Äôs my condensed version:

1. Identify Necessary Controls
Use institutional knowledge to determine what makes assignment as-good-as-random.
Patent example: Assignment is random within art unit √ó year, so these are necessary controls.


2. Test Balance
Run UJIVE with predetermined covariates as outcomes. Significant coefficients = red flag.
Why UJIVE for balance tests? Same estimator, consistent approach. Other approaches (regressing covariates on constructed leniency) can show spurious imbalance due to finite-sample bias.


3. Estimate with UJIVE
Use UJIVE as primary estimator. Report 2SLS and OLS for comparison.
Software: Authors provide R package at github.com/kolesarm/ManyIV
library(ManyIV)
result <- ujive(
  formula = outcome ~ treatment | examiner_dummies | controls,
  data = your_data
)


4. Test Monotonicity
For heterogeneous effects interpretation (LATE), you need monotonicity: no defiers.
Test: Run UJIVE with outcome = indicator(outcome value) √ó treatment. Estimates should be ‚àà [0,1].
What it tests: ‚ÄúAverage monotonicity‚Äù‚Äîaverage leniency of examiners who‚Äôd approve exceeds those who‚Äôd deny.


5. Characterize Compliers
Run UJIVE with covariate √ó treatment as outcome to estimate complier characteristics.
Why: Check external validity. If compliers look very different from full sample, LATE estimates may not generalize.

title: Understanding Leniency Designs: Why Your Examiner Matters (And How to Estimate It Right)
section: When SHOULD You Use Leniency Designs?
text:
When SHOULD You Use Leniency Designs?
Leniency designs are powerful, but they require specific conditions:
‚úÖ Use leniency designs when:

Decision-makers are (quasi-)randomly assigned
Decision-makers have discretion and vary in leniency
The exclusion restriction is plausible (assignment only affects outcomes through the decision)
You can justify necessary controls for as-good-as-random assignment

‚ùå Don‚Äôt use leniency designs when:

Assignment is based on case characteristics (selection on observables)
Decision-makers do things beyond the binary decision (violates exclusion)
You can‚Äôt credibly argue for as-good-as-random assignment

Examples of good applications: - Patent examiners (random within art unit) - Bail judges (random within court-date-time) - Disability examiners (often random within office) - Loan officers (if rotational assignment)
Examples of problematic applications: - Judges who also provide advice (exclusion violation) - Assignment based on case complexity (not as-good-as-random) - Very few decisions per decision-maker (weak instruments)

title: Understanding Leniency Designs: Why Your Examiner Matters (And How to Estimate It Right)
text:
Software Implementation
The authors provide an R package for UJIVE:
# Install from GitHub
devtools::install_github("kolesarm/ManyIV")

library(ManyIV)

# Basic usage
result <- ujive(
  formula = outcome ~ treatment | examiner1 + examiner2 + ... | controls,
  data = your_data
)
The package handles: - Leave-one-out estimation - Heteroskedasticity-robust standard errors - Automatic dropping of collinear instruments/controls - Balance tests - Complier characterization

title: Understanding Leniency Designs: Why Your Examiner Matters (And How to Estimate It Right)
text:
Key Takeaways

Leniency designs are powerful when decision-makers are randomly assigned and vary in discretion
Standard 2SLS breaks down with many examiners due to mechanical correlation
UJIVE solves the problem through leave-one-out estimation
The bias can be large: With 50 examiners, 2SLS can have bias equal to 60% of OLS bias
Standard errors matter too: 2SLS standard errors are artificially small
Use UJIVE, not 2SLS for credible estimates with honest uncertainty

title: Understanding Leniency Designs: Why Your Examiner Matters (And How to Estimate It Right)
text:
Conclusion
Leniency designs offer a powerful way to estimate causal effects when randomization isn‚Äôt possible. But as we‚Äôve seen, the details of implementation matter enormously. Using 2SLS with many examiners can lead to biased estimates and misleadingly small standard errors‚Äîmaking weak effects look strong and uncertain effects look precise.
UJIVE provides a robust solution that works even when you have hundreds of decision-makers and complex control structures. The leave-one-out principle is simple but profound: by excluding each observation from its own instrument calculation, we break the mechanical correlation that plagues standard approaches.
For researchers using leniency designs, the message is clear: use UJIVE, not 2SLS. Your estimates will be more credible, your standard errors will be honest, and your conclusions will be more reliable.

title: Understanding Leniency Designs: Why Your Examiner Matters (And How to Estimate It Right)
text:
The Selection Bias Problem
Let‚Äôs start with why we need these fancy methods in the first place. Suppose we want to estimate:
\[y_i = \gamma + \beta x_i + \varepsilon_i\]
where \(y_i\) is future innovation (say, number of future patent applications), \(x_i\) is whether patent \(i\) was approved, and \(\beta\) is the causal effect we want.
The problem? Selection bias. Startups with strong applications are both:

More likely to get patents approved
More likely to innovate anyway (high \(\varepsilon_i\))

This correlation between \(x_i\) and \(\varepsilon_i\) means ordinary least squares (OLS) will overestimate the true causal effect.
Let me show you with a simulation:

    Figure 1: The Selection Bias Problem
    
        
        
            ‚óè Denied applications ¬†¬†
            ‚óè Approved applications
        
    




What‚Äôs happening here? Approved applications (green) have higher innovation, but this is partly because they had higher quality to begin with. OLS attributes the entire difference to the treatment, leading to severe overestimation.

title: Understanding Leniency Designs: Why Your Examiner Matters (And How to Estimate It Right)
text:
The Instrumental Variables Solution
The solution is to find variation in approval that‚Äôs unrelated to quality. Enter examiner leniency.

The Simple Two-Examiner Case
Let‚Äôs start with just two examiners:

Examiner T (Tough): Approves 40% of applications

Examiner S (Soft): Approves 70% of applications

If assignment is random, we can use examiner assignment as an instrument for approval. The IV estimator is just:
\[\hat{\beta}_{IV} = \frac{E[y_i | \text{assigned to S}] - E[y_i | \text{assigned to T}]}{P(\text{approved} | \text{assigned to S}) - P(\text{approved} | \text{assigned to T})}\]
This is the famous Wald estimator. Let‚Äôs see it in action:

    Figure 2: The Instrumental Variables Approach with Two Examiners
    
        
            Tough examiner approval rate:
            
            0.40
        
        
            Soft examiner approval rate:
            
            0.70
        
        Regenerate Data
    
    
        
    




Why this works: Examiner assignment is random, so it‚Äôs uncorrelated with quality (\(\varepsilon_i\)). But it affects approval probability (relevance). And it only affects innovation through the approval decision (exclusion). Perfect instrument!

title: Leniency Designs: Why You‚Äôve Been Doing Them Wrong (And How to Fix It)
text:
Quick Refresher: The Leniency Design
You probably know this cold, but let‚Äôs establish notation. Consider the outcome equation:
\[y_i = \gamma + \beta x_i + \varepsilon_i\]
where:

\(y_i\) is the outcome (e.g., future innovation for startup \(i\))
\(x_i \in \{0,1\}\) is treatment (e.g., patent approval)
\(\beta\) is the causal effect we want
\(\varepsilon_i\) captures unobservables

The identification problem: \(x_i\) and \(\varepsilon_i\) are correlated. Patents go to better startups, bail is granted to safer defendants, etc. OLS is biased.
The leniency design solution: Cases are randomly assigned to decision-makers \(j = 1, \ldots, K\) who vary in leniency. Let \(z_i\) be a vector of examiner indicators (one for each examiner, minus a reference category). The first-stage regression is:
\[x_i = z_i'\pi + w_i'\delta + \nu_i\]
where \(w_i\) are necessary controls (e.g., art unit √ó year FE in patent setting) and \(\pi\) captures examiner leniencies relative to the omitted examiner.
Why it works: Random assignment means \(z_i \perp \varepsilon_i | w_i\). Variation in leniency means \(\pi \neq 0\). Standard 2SLS instruments with \(z_i\) (controlling for \(w_i\)) to estimate \(\beta\).

The Simple Two-Examiner Case
To build intuition, consider just two examiners: one tough (\(t\)), one soft (\(s\)). Let \(p_t\) and \(p_s\) be their approval rates, with \(p_s > p_t\). With a single binary instrument \(z_i \in \{0,1\}\) indicating assignment to the soft examiner, the IV estimator simplifies to the Wald estimator:
\[\hat{\beta}_{IV} = \frac{E[y_i | z_i = 1] - E[y_i | z_i = 0]}{E[x_i | z_i = 1] - E[x_i | z_i = 0]} = \frac{\bar{y}_s - \bar{y}_t}{p_s - p_t}\]
Let‚Äôs see this in action:

    Figure 1: The Two-Examiner IV Estimator
    
        
            Tough examiner approval rate:
            
            0.40
        
        
            Soft examiner approval rate:
            
            0.70
        
        Regenerate Data
    
    
        
    



With just two examiners, IV works beautifully. The estimate recovers the true effect. Standard errors are straightforward (het-robust, no clustering needed since assignment is iid).
The key insight: This works because examiner assignment is uncorrelated with \(\varepsilon_i\) by random assignment. The Wald estimator identifies a local average treatment effect (LATE) for compliers‚Äîcases that would be approved by the soft examiner but denied by the tough one.

title: Leniency Designs: Why You‚Äôve Been Doing Them Wrong (And How to Fix It)
text:
The Problem: Many Instruments
In practice, you never have two examiners. Patent offices have hundreds of examiners, courts have dozens of judges, disability offices have many screeners. With \(K\) examiners, you have \(K-1\) instruments (the examiner dummies).
This is where things break down.

The Mechanical Correlation
The standard 2SLS approach:

First stage: Regress \(x_i\) on all examiner dummies \(z_i\) (and controls \(w_i\))
Get predicted values: \(\hat{x}_i = z_i'\hat{\pi} + w_i'\hat{\delta}\)
Second stage: Regress \(y_i\) on \(\hat{x}_i\) (and controls)

Here‚Äôs the problem: \(\hat{x}_i\) is the predicted approval probability for application \(i\) based on examiner \(j\)‚Äôs approval rate. But that approval rate is calculated using all observations assigned to examiner \(j\)‚Äîincluding observation \(i\) itself!
If examiner \(j\) handled 50 cases and observation \(i\) is one of them, then \(\hat{x}_i\) is mechanically correlated with \(x_i\). And since \(x_i\) is correlated with \(\varepsilon_i\) (that‚Äôs why we need IV!), this means \(\hat{x}_i\) is correlated with \(\varepsilon_i\).
Your instrument is contaminated.

The Bias Formula
Under homoskedasticity, the paper shows that 2SLS bias can be approximated as:
\[\text{Bias}(2SLS) \approx \text{Bias}(OLS) \times \frac{1}{E[F]}\]
where \(E[F]\) is the expected value of the first-stage F-statistic.
The famous ‚ÄúF > 10‚Äù rule of thumb says you want \(E[F] > 10\) to keep 2SLS bias below 10% of OLS bias. But with many examiners, \(E[F]\) can be small even when examiners collectively explain meaningful variation, because \(F\) is divided by \(K-1\).
Key insight from the paper: The bias isn‚Äôt just about weak instruments in the traditional sense. Even with ‚Äústrong enough‚Äù first stages, the own-observation contamination creates bias.



Simulation: Watching the Bias Grow
Let‚Äôs see this in action. I‚Äôll simulate data with many examiners and show how 2SLS gets pulled toward OLS as \(K\) increases:

    Figure 2: The Many-Examiner Bias Problem
    
        
            Number of examiners (K):
            
            50
        
        
            Sample size (n):
            
            1000
        
        Run Simulation (500 iterations)
    
    
        
        
    




What you‚Äôre seeing: As \(K\) increases relative to \(n\), 2SLS (blue) gets pulled toward OLS (red). UJIVE (purple) stays centered on the true effect. This isn‚Äôt a weak instruments problem in the traditional sense‚Äîthe examiners collectively explain meaningful variation. It‚Äôs the mechanical correlation from including own-observation data.



The Standard Error Problem
But wait, there‚Äôs more! The bias in point estimates is only half the story. The paper shows that 2SLS standard errors are also wrong‚Äîand in a way that masks the bias problem.
Look at the distributions above. Notice how 2SLS (blue) is super concentrated? That narrow spike means small variance, which means small standard errors. But those small SEs aren‚Äôt reflecting true precision‚Äîthey‚Äôre an artifact of the same overfitting that causes the bias.
Here‚Äôs what happens:

2SLS overstates the predictive power of the instruments (includes own-observation data)
This inflates the denominator in the IV formula: \(\sum \hat{\ell}_i^2\) instead of \(\sum \tilde{\ell}_i^2\)
The SE formula has that same denominator, so SEs are too small
Result: you get tight confidence intervals around a biased estimate

This is dangerous. You see small p-values and think you‚Äôve precisely estimated a large effect. In reality, you‚Äôve imprecisely estimated a smaller effect.
UJIVE fixes both problems. That wider purple distribution reflects honest uncertainty‚Äîlarger SEs that correctly account for: - Estimation error in leniency measures - Heterogeneous treatment effects across complier groups
- Many-instrument uncertainty

The tradeoff: UJIVE sacrifices some efficiency (larger SEs) to eliminate bias and get correct inference. 2SLS looks precise but is both biased and has wrong SEs. You‚Äôd rather have honest uncertainty around an unbiased estimate than false precision around a biased one.

title: Leniency Designs: Why You‚Äôve Been Doing Them Wrong (And How to Fix It)
text:
The Solution: UJIVE
The fix is elegant. Instead of including observation \(i\) when estimating its examiner‚Äôs leniency, leave it out.

The Leave-One-Out Principle
For each observation \(i\) assigned to examiner \(j\):

Estimate examiner \(j\)‚Äôs leniency using all observations except \(i\): \[\hat{\ell}_{-i}\]
Use this leave-one-out leniency as the instrument for \(i\)
Repeat for all observations

This breaks the mechanical correlation. Since \(\hat{\ell}_{-i}\) doesn‚Äôt depend on \(x_i\), it can‚Äôt be mechanically correlated with \(\varepsilon_i\).
Let me visualize exactly what this means:

    Figure 3: The Leave-One-Out Principle
    
        
    




The UJIVE Estimator
Formally, UJIVE is:
\[\hat{\beta}_{UJIVE} = \frac{\sum_i \hat{\ell}_{-i} y_i}{\sum_i \hat{\ell}_{-i} x_i}\]
where \(\hat{\ell}_{-i}\) is the leave-one-out predicted leniency for observation \(i\).
Why this works: Since \(\hat{\ell}_{-i}\) doesn‚Äôt use \(i\)‚Äôs own data, it‚Äôs independent of \((x_i, \varepsilon_i)\) conditional on \(w_i\). No mechanical correlation, no bias.
Key properties: - Approximately unbiased even with many weak instruments - Correct standard errors accounting for heterogeneous effects - Doesn‚Äôt require strong first stage (\(F > 10\) rule doesn‚Äôt apply) - Computationally simple (one-step estimator)



Does It Actually Work?
Let‚Äôs run a big simulation comparing all three estimators:

    Figure 4: Full Comparison - 1,000 Simulations
    
        
        
            Run 1,000 Simulations (K=50, n=1000)
        
        
    




The key takeaway: Look at the standard deviations in the table. UJIVE has larger SD (and thus larger standard errors) than 2SLS. This is a feature, not a bug. UJIVE‚Äôs wider distribution reflects honest uncertainty‚Äîit correctly accounts for estimation error in leniency measures and heterogeneous effects. 2SLS‚Äôs tight distribution is false precision.
You‚Äôd rather have truthful uncertainty around an unbiased estimate than false confidence around a biased one.

title: Leniency Designs: Why You‚Äôve Been Doing Them Wrong (And How to Fix It)

Empirical Application: Patent Values Revisited

What Changed?

The Impact of Batching Advanced Imaging Tests in Emergency Departments


Jacob Jameson, Soroush Saghafian, Robert Huckman, Nicole Hodgson, Joshua Baugh


When a patient arrives in the ED with chest pain, should the physician order a CT scan and ultrasound together, or wait for CT results first? This batch vs.¬†sequence decision affects both efficiency and diagnostic quality‚Äîbut we know little about how physicians actually make it. Using EMR data from 50,000+ ED visits, I document substantial physician-level variation in batching tendencies and estimate that high-batching physicians have 4.5% longer patient stays but 14.8% fewer 72-hour return admissions. I develop a structural model to characterize when batching versus sequencing is optimal, providing actionable guidance for ED workflow design.

quarto render
This generates static HTML output to the docs/ directory, which is served by GitHub Pages.

quarto render index.qmd

Defines website structure, navigation, and metadata
Sets output directory to docs/ for GitHub Pages
Configures theme (flatly with custom theme-light.scss)
Includes Google Analytics tracking

index.qmd: Homepage with animated typing effect, about section, and news feed
